question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Suppose we are given 4 points (\emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{1}), (\emph{x}\textsubscript{2},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{2}), (\emph{x}\textsubscript{3},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{3}) and (\emph{x}\textsubscript{4},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{4}) in the plane and we want to find a function
\emph{$f$(x)}, defined for $x_1 \leq x \leq x_4$, whose graph interpolates
these points. Assume that

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}
p_1(x) & \text{for } x_1 \leq x \leq x_2 \\
p_2(x) & \text{for } x_2 \leq x \leq x_3 \\
p_3(x) & \text{for } x_3 \leq x \leq x_4
\end{cases}\end{align*}

where each \emph{p}\textsubscript{i}(\emph{x}) is a polynomial.

\textbf{(a)} What equations, written in terms of
\emph{p}\textsubscript{i}(\emph{x}) and possibly their derivatives,
express the condition that \emph{$f$(x)} goes through the given points? Do
the equations imply that \emph{$f$(x)} is continuous?
sols:
Since the piece-wise function above has inclusive restrictions, we can
see that both polynomials, $p_1$ and $p_2$, have the same value
$f(x_2)$. The same goes for polynomials $p_2$ and $p_3$.

Thus, we need to satisfy

\begin{align*}\displaystyle p_i(x) = p_{i+1}(x)\end{align*}

Therefore,

\begin{align*}
p_1(x_2) = p_2(x_2)\\
p_2(x_3) = p_3(x_3)\end{align*}

Hence these equations imply that $f(x)$ is continuous as they show that
both polynomials surrounding the given point equal each other at $x_i$.

As well, to show that the function goes through the given points, we
need to write the following six equations:

\begin{align*}
p_{1}(x_{1}) = y_{1}\\
p_{1}(x_{2}) = y_{2}\\
p_{2}(x_{2}) = y_{2}\\
p_{2}(x_{3}) = y_{3}\\
p_{3}(x_{3}) = y_{3}\\
p_{3}(x_{4}) = y_{4}\end{align*}
hints:
The condition that \emph{$f$(x)} goes through all the points means that
\emph{$f$(x\textsubscript{i}) = y\textsubscript{i}}. Rewrite this in terms
of \emph{p\textsubscript{i}(x)}.
